overview_info.Subject:
Das Art History gehört zum Studienbereiche Kunst- und Design sciences, Kunstpädagogik der Fächergruppe Art, Music, Design.Weitere Informationen zur Fächergruppe Art, Music, Design.
                                                Art History

Target group:
Art History in Tübingen represents in research and teaching the entire bandwidth of the subject, from the Late Antiquity to the present.
The spectrum ranges from the visual arts through architecture and applied arts to photography, film, electronically generated media and genre-defying artistic processes.
The Tübingen Master’s in Art History is characterised by its media-historical breadth and practical relevance, which is defined by the institute's graphic collection and the large art collections of the region.
The Master’s programme also benefits from the interdisciplinary range of courses at the University of Tübingen.
Studying in the “Alte Burse”, the oldest university building in the middle of the old town of Tübingen on the banks of the river Neckar. Founded in 1894, the institute has a graphic collection, an extensive library with over 50,000 volumes, is equipped to the latest technical standards and has its own image database. 
A broad-based and up-to-date teaching programme, attractive secondary courses and the high density of museums, exhibition halls and art monuments in the region make Tübingen an ideal location for studying art history.

overview_info.course_name: Art History: Architecture and Art in the context of Cultural History
overview_info.Subject:
Das Art History gehört zum Studienbereiche Kunst- und Design sciences, Kunstpädagogik der Fächergruppe Art, Music, Design.Weitere Informationen zur Fächergruppe Art, Music, Design.
                                                Art History
overview_info.Areas of Concentration: Architecture and Art in a Cultural History Context

Target group: Graduates of a Bachelor's degree or equivalent degree in the subject of Art History
Annotation of the Higher Education Insti: With its traditional key areas in Europe and North America, Art History examines the genres architecture, painting, graphics, sculpture, arts and crafts, and also town planning, landscape and garden art. The period of the Modern Age (19th to the 21st Century) is complemented by photography, film and electronic media (video, computer). Whilst examining the art of the Modern Age, non-European and non-American trends and influences are also taken into account.Key research areas in Osnabrück include architecture and visual arts of the Middle Ages and the Early Modern Age, especially in France, Italy and Germany. Proof of good command of English and one other subject-relevant language is therefore essential. In addition, special attention is paid to the history of art in Lower Saxony.The examination regulations do not stipulate a compulsory stay abroad. It is possible, however, to complete a stay abroad at European and non-European universities in the context of various exchange programmes.On the one hand, the Master's degree qualifies students for employment in science and opens up the opportunity for doctoral studies and, with the appropriate course planning/fulfilment of the relevant requirements, admission to any possible doctorate\\\; In accordance with this, admission to the PhD programme on Migration Research and Intercultural Studies at the Universität Osnabrück.The degree course also qualifies students for a wide range of careers in authorities linked to the preservation of historical monuments, in museums, in adult education institutions, the press, publishing, radio, film and television, in local positions for public relations, in cultural offices as well as for galleries and art foundations.

admission_reqs_info.Completion of first university degree: Bachelor/Bakkalaureus                                            (and other qualifications, provided that they are recognised as being equivalent)

Das Intercultural Studies gehört zum Studienbereiche Cultural Studies der Fächergruppe Language and Cultural Studies.Weitere Informationen zur Fächergruppe Language and Cultural Studies.
                                                Intercultural Studies

Target group:
The aim of the integrated courses Mainz-Dijon is the acquisition of two degrees, both nationally recognised after successful completion of a relevant degree course. The German university awards the Master of Arts (MA); the French University awards the Master Recherche (Master's in Research).
In addition to the binational specialist training in two educational systems, the acquisition of intercultural competencies is an important component of the course. Compared to regular courses of study, the integrated courses not only offer a double degree, but also educate students for the international labour market without extending the time they spend studying.
Annotation of the Higher Education Insti: Students are advised to commence studies in the winter semester.If the Bachelor degree certificate is not available by the application deadline, but at least 135 credit points can be demonstrated: Submit a certificate of study and examinations and the average grade achieved so far. (This certificate must be issued by the relevant higher education, original or officially authenticated copy). If the degree was obtained abroad: officially authenticated copy of a certificate of recognition (responsible: Student Service - Admission International).After enrolment, the diploma must be submitted.

                                                Art History
overview_info.Areas of Concentration: Film Science for Art Historians, Christian Archaeology and Byzantine Art History, Scientific Basics and Foundation Skills, Classical Archaeology for Art Historians, Musicology for Art Historians, Law for Art Historians, Theatre Studies for Art Historians

Target group: The Master's programme in Art History: Works-Contexts-Discourses provides students with an extensive range of options of studying the history and theory of visual and applied arts and architecture in chronological and methodological breadth. The course aims to provide an academically qualified, research-oriented degree that enables entry to all careers in which reflective analysis, evaluation and teaching of material evidence of the history of art and culture plays a role in all its facets and contexts of application.
Annotation of the Higher Education Insti: If the Bachelor degree certificate is not available by the application deadline, but at least 135 credit points can be demonstrated: Submit a certificate of study and examinations and the average grade achieved so far. (This certificate must be issued by the relevant higher education, original or officially authenticated copy). If the degree was obtained abroad: officially authenticated copy of a certificate of recognition (responsible: Student Service - Admission International).After enrolment, the diploma must be submitted.
